Based on my search results, I can provide you with information about "Quo Vadis" and its modern references across internet culture, social media, gaming, tourism, and Rome. Here's what I found:

## Modern Social Media and Academic Usage

"Quo Vadis" has been adopted in academic and social media research, particularly in studies examining the future of social media platforms including Facebook, Instagram, WeChat, WhatsApp, TikTok, and YouTube. The phrase appears in research titles exploring how social media platforms "have become a crucial and omnipresent cultural and economic phenomenon".

## TikTok and Social Media Content

The Domine Quo Vadis church in Rome has become popular content on TikTok, with several creators making educational videos about the site:

- Christian content creators on TikTok share videos about the church, explaining the biblical story and its significance
- Travel guides create Rome tourism content featuring the church and its historical significance
- Educational church content creators use hashtags like #rome #italy #church #bible #jesus #god #history #christian #stories #education #fyp

## Gaming References

There was a notable 1984 Commodore 64 video game called "Quo Vadis" - an action-adventure game where players explored caverns to retrieve a scepter, featuring one of the largest game worlds of its time with 1024 screen sizes. The game received Game of the Month recognition in Personal Computer Games magazine.

## Meme Culture

The phrase appears in meme generators, with users creating "Quo Vadis" memes using platforms like Make a Meme. There are also GIFs and animated content featuring the phrase on platforms like GIPHY.

## Rome Tourism and Modern References

The Chiesa del Domine Quo Vadis in Rome marks the legendary spot where St. Peter met Jesus, asking "Domine, quo vadis?" (Lord, where are you going?), to which Jesus replied, "Venio Roman iterum crucifigi" (I am coming to Rome to be crucified again). 

The church stands about 800 meters from Porta San Sebastiano on the Via Appia Antica, and contains copies of Christ's footprints, with the originals preserved in the Basilica di San Sebastiano.

## Cultural Impact

The 1951 MGM film "Quo Vadis" significantly shaped modern movie-going audiences' perceptions of ancient Rome and helped establish the "sword-and-sandal" film genre.

The phrase continues to be used metaphorically in discussions about social media's impact on society, with some arguing it helps move toward "creative ways to evangelise but also responsible ways".

The phrase "Quo Vadis" has evolved from its ancient Christian origins to become a versatile reference point in modern internet culture, appearing in academic research about social media futures, gaming, tourism content on TikTok, and general meme culture.
